I came in wanting to study psychology to help people. But the psychology classes I took didn‚Äôt give me the feeling that I was actually learning how to do that. I studied a lot, learned a ton across different subjects - but still felt lost. People would come to me with their problems, and even with everything I knew, I couldn‚Äôt really help them.

Then I joined the Person-Centered Counseling class, and it completely changed everything. There, I learned how to talk to people, how to reflect their emotions, how to affirm their strengths, and how to provide information and inspire hope. After that, everything just started to make sense. I finally had a channel - a way to put what I‚Äôd learned into practice. I felt reborn and motivated. In some way, the class inspired me just like how it taught me to inspire people, and I think that‚Äôs - very cool.

When I started at Fulbright, I was just kind of... lost. I came in straight from high school, where I didn‚Äôt try very hard. I didn‚Äôt think I was smart. I didn‚Äôt think I was anything, really. Most of my time was spent gaming, staying inside, avoiding stuff. I was passive, quiet, and honestly didn‚Äôt know how to handle life. I wasn‚Äôt miserable, but I wasn‚Äôt doing great either.

At Fulbright, everything hit me fast. The workload, the expectations, the people who actually knew what they were doing. I had no clue how to keep up. Classes were tough. Juggling readings, chores, gym, food - it was a lot. I got overwhelmed. A lot. But I kept pushing through, even when I felt like I was drowning.

There wasn‚Äôt a single ‚Äúaha‚Äù moment for me - it was more like a slow, messy climb. Every semester I learned a little more, failed a little less. I started showing up to class prepared. I joined conversations. I asked questions. Sometimes I even had answers. I started seeing myself differently‚Äînot as someone who‚Äôs just trying to keep up, but as someone who actually belongs here.

And somewhere in the middle of all this, I stopped hiding. I started making friends. Talking to people. Being present. Not perfectly, not all at once - but enough to notice the difference. I even started helping others with their own stuff, using what I‚Äôd learned. That part still surprises me sometimes.

I‚Äôm still figuring things out. I still want to be a counselor, and now that dream feels a little more real. I have a long way to go, but at least now I‚Äôm walking in the right direction.

To my parents - thank you. I don‚Äôt say it enough, but I love you. Everything I‚Äôve done here, I owe to your support and belief in me. I‚Äôm going to try my best to make you proud.

Fulbright wasn‚Äôt just a place I studied - it was the place I grew up. Slowly. Awkwardly. But honestly. And that‚Äôs what I‚Äôll remember most.

I‚Äôm deeply grateful for the person I‚Äôve become at Fulbright. Student Life here has been the best thing that ever happened to me. I‚Äôll never forget our very first Orientation week‚Äîheld online due to COVID-19‚Äîyet still so complete. Among all the sessions, the one that changed me the most was Boundary Setting. It shaped the way every Fulbright student treats others, and it continues to influence how I navigate relationships today.

From Residential Life to Wellness and Learning Support, try-out events to work-study programs‚Äîevery experience has helped me grow, often even more than academic lectures. My first WSP, working as an IT Assistant, was especially transformative. I still remember the first time I met the IT staff, I nervously asked: ‚ÄúWill it be extremely embarrassing if someone asks a technical question and you don‚Äôt know the answer?‚Äù One of them simply said, ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs normal.‚Äù That moment gave me the confidence to show up in class platforms, to fix things when I could, and to ask for help when I couldn‚Äôt.

That role opened the door to meeting so many faculty and staff members, forming relationships that turned into unforgettable memories‚Äîtrips together, grabbing c√° vi√™n chi√™n in District 3, even staying in touch after they resigned. It also led me to become an AA Assistant, where I explored the behind-the-scenes world of university administration. column11:
The journey only truly began when we moved to offline learning in Spring 2022 and moved to the Waterfront. Living in shared dorms taught me how to embrace diversity, resolve conflicts, and accept that being different is not just okay‚Äîit‚Äôs valuable. I came into Fulbright as an 18-year-old still unsure of myself. But through my peers, I met the real me, and learn to embrace my unique values.

It was these amazing roommates who encouraged me to run for Student Council President in the AY23‚Äì24. I never imagined myself leading a team‚ÄîI‚Äôd never done it before‚Äîbut they believed in me. And their belief gave me the courage to believe in myself.

And then, there‚Äôs Running Club. A place where it doesn‚Äôt matter if I run slowly‚Äîor walk most of the time. The energy, the laughter, the encouragement from both friends and coaches made every run (and every walk) feel meaningful. Without them, the past few years could have felt dark and directionless. I always finished 21km right at the cut off time, yet they never make fun of me when I said I want to finish 42km before I graduate. I never thought I could become one who finds joy in running, but now, I am. And the motto we hold for running applies to every other achievement in life: take small steps, consistently.

It‚Äôs not about what I‚Äôve achieved‚Äîbut about the belief I now carry within me. Fulbright has given me the faith that, whatever comes my way, I‚Äôll be ready to face it‚Äîand I‚Äôll nail it.

Fulbright wasn‚Äôt where my college life started, but it‚Äôs where I finally got out of idle mode and into full operation. Transferring here felt like switching from closed-loop to open-loop control. suddenly, I had the freedom to explore, fail, recalibrate, and run wild. I was on the ground floor, running real-world tests with real machines, and real consequences.

Most of our projects were‚Ä¶ let‚Äôs call them ‚Äúnonlinear systems with unmeasurable disturbances.‚Äù Things overheated. Circuits fried. Hours of debugging. But every disaster added data to the feedback loop for better performance.

Outside the lab, I joined the Fulbright Ultimate Club, basically a dynamic system where friends act as both actuator and projectile. Great for cardio. Even better for learning real-time decision-making under high stress and humidity.

Now I‚Äôm leaving with shaky hands, burnt fingers, and a system memory full of well-earned errors. I came in as a student. I‚Äôm leaving as a high-risk, high-reward prototype, with fully tested, slightly unstable, and absolutely ready for deployment.

When I first stepped into Fulbright, I wasn‚Äôt looking for answers ‚Äî I was looking for permission to explore. And Fulbright gave me just that.

It didn‚Äôt mold me into a fixed shape. It gave me space to unfold.

The authentic learning culture encouraged me to try, fail, rethink, and design my own learning process. Professors didn‚Äôt just lecture ‚Äî they listened. Classmates didn‚Äôt compete ‚Äî they collaborated. I didn‚Äôt just study, I grew.

The diversity of thought here was not decorative, it was foundational. From anthropology to applied mathematics, from philosophy circles to activism workshops, I found myself navigating different ways of thinking and being. It reshaped how I approached knowledge ‚Äî not as a trophy to claim, but a lens to question the world.

The collaborative spirit at Fulbright meant everything. No matter where you turned ‚Äî the Library, Student Life, the classroom, even the Crescent Lake  ‚Äî you‚Äôd find someone who‚Äôd walk beside you, share a laugh, or gently challenge your ideas.

Above all, it was the community of empathy that transformed me. Not just being heard, but being truly seen. Whether it was in a office hour, a community check-in, or a quiet look exchanged in a tough moment ‚Äî I realized what a rare thing it is to feel both free and supported at once.

I will leave Fulbright not with a fixed identity, but a toolkit: to listen deeply, to collaborate across difference, to fail gracefully, to think with heart. I carry forward a belief in education as transformation, not transaction.

To those who are just beginning: don‚Äôt try to fit in. Be curious. Be weird. Be kind. Your journey will not look like anyone else‚Äôs ‚Äî and that‚Äôs the point.

Thank you, Fulbright ‚Äî for not shaping me, but for letting me shape myself.

‚ÄúVoiceless‚Äù was the title of my entrance essay to Fulbright. It talked about the unheard stories of villains in fairy tales and how I empathize with them for being a misfit right in my own home. Bad versus evil, Ian must be glad that his teaching about ‚Äúslave morality‚Äù touched me deeply. I started as a tempered high school kid trying to get myself out of the home where I felt misunderstood. Now, I find myself back in that same place, transforming both the love and pain into arts that I hold dear. I no longer want to purge the bad memories or cover them up with new ones. ‚ÄúEthnographic gold,‚Äù ch·ªã Tr√¢m would say, reminding me of how I can see through these bad memories and faded pain to learn more about my lineage. 

Now, I consider myself an intellectual nomad and an art practitioner who pays close attention to established institutions to pose questions about agency, identity, and phenomenology. Blending ethnographic works and art making, I see myself as a channeller, through which social forces materialize as visual patterns, sound waves, and words. In Bodies That Become Spatial (2024), a series of 30 low-exposure photographs, me and Hoang (my roommate) turned the Exit hall, a site where identities are suspended, into a workshop of meaning-making, spinning webs of light that stands in for the morphology of identities. In The Playgrounds (2025), a two-minute stereo audio mix, I cast myself in a self-made urban horror movie, grappling with the compressing adulthood in an exploitative neoliberal cityscape. Recently, with a new interest in making gastronomic reviews, I examined the aesthetics and taste of food reviewers including myself. Getting to know Michelin‚Äôs entangled history of being both a global gastronomic curator and a rubber baron with various plantations in Indochina, I wrote a preliminary research paper to explore how Michelin employs aesthetics and mystification to dissociate from its colonial history in Indochina, reframing its identity through the particular language of global culinary excellence.

column10: What I cherish most about Fulbright is the freedom to reinvent myself. It‚Äôs a place where there are no set paths, allowing me to explore new interests and redefine who I am. At Fulbright, I can be a scholar, an artist, or an activist without the pressure of fitting into one box. The freedom to fail has been key to this reinvention. Unlike traditional academic settings, where failure often feels like a setback, here it‚Äôs seen as part of the learning process. I‚Äôm encouraged to experiment and take risks without the fear of being judged. This has helped me grow academically and personally. Fulbright has allowed me to branch out beyond my original field of study, blending multiple disciplines that enrich my thinking. It‚Äôs given me the chance to explore different sides of myself‚Äîboth as a student and as an individual. I‚Äôve learned to embrace vulnerability, something I didn‚Äôt do before, and I‚Äôve grown more open-minded and compassionate. Beyond academics, Fulbright has helped me understand my place in Vietnam and my role in the country‚Äôs future. It‚Äôs a space where I can challenge ideas, reflect on my identity, and contribute to a larger conversation about the world. The autonomy to shape my own education has been empowering. Fulbright doesn‚Äôt just offer a rigid curriculum; I‚Äôve been able to pursue what excites me and take ownership of my learning. This flexibility has been crucial in my personal growth.

I can still remember the first day I stepped onto the Fulbright campus: excited, nervous, and maybe just a little bit overwhelmed. I was stepping into an environment that was totally new to me. But as soon as I walked through the doors, I felt something different. It wasn‚Äôt just the beautiful campus or the impressive facilities, it was the energy. The energy of people who were as excited to learn and explore as I was, people who weren‚Äôt afraid to challenge ideas and push boundaries.

When I first came to Fulbright, I thought I knew exactly what I wanted. I had my major, my goals, my expectations. But what I didn‚Äôt know was that Fulbright would change everything. It‚Äôs here that I learned how to reinvent myself. I started with one set of ideas, but I‚Äôve evolved so much since then, academically, personally, and creatively. Fulbright gave me the space to try things I never would have attempted before. To explore new passions, meet people from different walks of life, and dive into fields I never thought would interest me. It pushed me to be a better version of myself, more confident, more open-minded, and more willing to embrace change and uncertainty.

There were moments, of course, when I doubted myself. Moments when I questioned my path or wondered if I was making the right choices. But those moments were part of the process. During my four years at Fulbright, I‚Äôve had both good and bad memories‚Äîbut I cherish them all, as they‚Äôve shaped who I am today. Among them, the military training course (MTC) stands out as the most beautiful and emotionally truthful experience I‚Äôve had.

There are two main reasons for this. First, MTC reminded me of my high school days. Unlike university life, where everyone is caught up in their own hustle, MTC placed us all in the same routine, same conditions, and same goal‚Äîmaking it out alive. Like high school, we studied, ate, and slept together. In that uniform setting, the only personal things we had were our emotions and relationships. With nothing else to distract us, we had all the time in the world to care for one another.

Second, the intensity of the training pushed us to find joy in the simplest, most organic ways. On the first day, I expected to keep to myself and get through it quietly. But the harsh summer heat and physical challenges brought us closer. We shared fans, food, jokes, drinks‚Äîand even moments of lying on the floor half-naked just to cool down. We supported each other through every chore and challenge, without conflict, because we knew we were all in the same boat.

It felt like rediscovering childhood with people my age‚Äîplaying, singing, and bonding like kids again. It was rare, raw, and something I‚Äôll carry with me for a long time.

What I cherish most about my time here is the permission I found to explore - the freedom to try things I had never even considered possible before.

Ultimately, my time at Fulbright taught me that education is an expansive journey. I learned that intellectual growth is intertwined with personal development and that every activity contributes to a richer, more complex sense of self. The chance to embrace so many different facets of learning has forever altered my outlook on life. I come from a mountainous region where access to higher education was a distant dream. This journey at Fulbright, which began in a small, remote village, has transformed me in ways I once only dared to imagine. My time at Fulbright is a tapestry woven with hardship, discovery, and triumph.

In my hometown, resources were scarce, and expectations were modest. Education was valued, but opportunities were limited. The decision to leave my mountainous home and venture to Saigon was both exhilarating and terrifying. Saigon, with its bustling energy and modern allure, was a stark contrast to my quiet, rugged upbringing. I arrived with a mix of excitement and apprehension, unsure if I would fit in or if I was even capable of achieving what many deemed impossible.

Studying at Fulbright was a turning point - a validation that my potential was recognized beyond the boundaries of my humble beginnings. It opened doors not just to academic excellence, but also to a world of experiences that I had never imagined I would encounter. At Fulbright, I was not just a student; I was a creator, a performer, a researcher, and ultimately, a person in the making.

Perhaps the most transformative aspect of my time at Fulbright was the community I found here. My classmates and professors came from diverse backgrounds, each bringing their own unique perspectives to the table. Our differences were not barriers‚Äîthey were bridges that connected us. In group projects, late-night study sessions, and spontaneous discussions about life and dreams, I discovered the power of collaboration and empathy. I made friends who challenged me to grow, who celebrated my successes, and who held my hand during moments of doubt. The support and understanding I received were beyond what I could have ever hoped for.

I learned to trust my instincts, to stand firm in my decisions, and to embrace the uncertainty of the future with open arms. Every setback was a lesson, every failure a testament to my resilience, and every success a glimpse of the person I was becoming.

The most profound impact of my Fulbright experience is how it reshaped my understanding of purpose. Coming from a normal background, I had always dreamed of a future where I could transcend the limitations imposed by my circumstances. Fulbright not only provided me with the education to pursue that dream‚Äîit instilled in me the confidence to believe that I could make a meaningful impact in the world. With my newfound skills and experiences, I was able to secure a job aligned with my passion for music‚Äîan area I had always loved but never imagined could be a viable career. This opportunity, born out of chance and nurtured by hard work, has given me the confidence to face every decision with a sense of purpose and determination.
